description: This is probably your first Corpus, you can use it to play with the app... When you want to make a real corpus, click New : Corpus

termsOfUse.humanReadable: Sample: The materials included in this corpus are available for research and educational use. If you want to use the materials for commercial purposes, please notify the author(s) of the corpus (myemail@myemail.org) prior to the use of the materials. Users of this corpus can copy and redistribute the materials included in this corpus, under the condition that the materials copied/redistributed are properly attributed.  Modification of the data in any copied/redistributed work is not allowed unless the data source is properly cited and the details of the modification is clearly mentioned in the work. Some of the items included in this corpus may be subject to further access conditions specified by the owners of the data and/or the authors of the corpus.

license.title: Default: Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike (CC BY-SA).
license.humanReadable: This license lets others remix, tweak, and build upon your work even for commercial purposes, as long as they credit you and license their new creations under the identical terms. This license is often compared to “copyleft” free and open source software licenses. All new works based on yours will carry the same license, so any derivatives will also allow commercial use. This is the license used by Wikipedia, and is recommended for materials that would benefit from incorporating content from Wikipedia and similarly licensed projects.

copyright: Default: Add names of the copyright holders of the corpus.

datumFields.help: Acceptablity judgement (*,#,?  mean this sentence is strange)
datumFields.helpLinguists: Grammaticality/acceptability judgement (*,#,?,1-3 etc). Leaving it blank usually means grammatical/acceptable, or your team can choose any symbol for this meaning.

datumFields.help: What was said/written in an alphabet the team is comfortable using.
datumFields.helpLinguists: Unparsed utterance in the language, in orthography or romanized or IPA transcription (what ever is commonly used for linguistic examples of this language.) Line 1 in your LaTeXed examples for handouts. Sample entry: amigas

datumFields.help: Words divided into prefixes, root and suffixes using a - between each eg: prefix-prefix-root-suffix-suffix-suffix
datumFields.helpLinguists: Morpheme-segmented utterance in the language. Used by the system to help generate glosses (below). Can optionally appear below (or instead of) the first line in your LaTeXed examples. Sample entry: amig-a-s

datumFields.help: Translation for each prefix, root and suffix in the words
datumFields.helpLinguists: Metalanguage glosses of each individual morpheme (above). Used by the system to help gloss, in combination with morphemes (above). It is Line 2 in your LaTeXed examples. We recommend Leipzig conventions (. for fusional morphemes, - for morpheme boundaries etc)  Sample entry: friend-fem-pl

datumFields.help: Translation into English/Spanish/Russian, or simply a language the team is comfortable with. There may also be additional languages in the other fields.
datumFields.helpLinguists: The team's primary translation. It might not be English, just a language the team is comfortable with (in which case you should change the lable to the language you are using). There may also be additional translations in the other fields.

datumFields.help: Linguistic/social context when this can be said.
datumFields.helpLinguists: Linguistic/social context when this can be said, or when it is semantically/pragmatically felicitous etc.

datumFields.help: Additional discussion of this example (for handouts or for documentation). Wiki or LaTeX formattable.
datumFields.helpLinguists: Additional discussion of this example (for handouts or for documentation). Wiki or LaTeX formattable.

datumFields.help: What was said/written using the alphabet/writing system of the language.
datumFields.helpLinguists: Many teams will only use the utterance line. However if your team needs to distinguish between utterance and orthography this is the unparsed word/sentence/dialog/paragraph/document in the language, in its native orthography. If there are more than one orthography an additional field can be added to the corpus. This is Line 0 in your LaTeXed examples for handouts (if you distinguish the orthography from the utterance line and you choose to display the orthography for your language consultants and/or native speaker linguists). Sample entry: amigas

datumFields.help: Words divided into prefixes, root and suffixes which match the spelling of the word (not necessarily the actual dictionary entry of the word) using a - between each eg: prefix-prefix-root-suffix-suffix-suffix
datumFields.helpLinguists: Surface realizations of the morpheme-segmented utterance in the language. Used by the system to help generate glosses (below). Usually does not appear in your LaTeX examples unless you are working on morpho-phonology. Sample entry: amig-a-s

datumFields.help: This optional field is used by the machine to help with search and data cleaning, in combination with morphemes and gloss (above). If you want to use it, you can choose to use any sort of syntactic category tagging you wish. It could be very theoretical like Distributed Morphology (Sample entry: √-GEN-NUM), or very a-theroretical like the Penn Tree Bank Tag Set. (Sample entry: NNS) http://www.ims.uni-stuttgart.de/projekte/CorpusWorkbench/CQP-HTMLDemo/PennTreebankTS.html
datumFields.helpLinguists: This optional field is used by the machine to help with search and data cleaning, in combination with morphemes and gloss (above). If you want to use it, you can choose to use any sort of syntactic category tagging you wish. It could be very theoretical like Distributed Morphology (Sample entry: √-GEN-NUM), or very a-theroretical like the Penn Tree Bank Tag Set. (Sample entry: NNS) http://www.ims.uni-stuttgart.de/projekte/CorpusWorkbench/CQP-HTMLDemo/PennTreebankTS.html

datumFields.help: Related data in the database, or at any web url.
datumFields.helpLinguists: Related data in the database, or at any web url.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: Related data in the database, or at any web url.

datumFields.help: Tags for constructions or other info that you might want to use to categorize your data.
datumFields.helpLinguists: Tags for constructions or other info that you might want to use to categorize your data.

datumFields.help: Tags about data validity. For example: ToBeCheckedBySeberina, CheckedByRicardo, Deleted etc...
datumFields.helpLinguists: Any number of tags of data validity. For example: ToBeCheckedBySeberina, CheckedByRicardo, Deleted etc...

datumFields.help: The user who originally entered this.
datumFields.helpLinguists: The user who originally entered this.

datumFields.help: An array of users who modified this
datumFields.helpLinguists: An array of users who modified this, this can optionally introduce a 'CheckedByUsername' into the datum's validation status if your team chooses.

datumFields.help: This optional field is used by the machine to make LaTeX trees and help with search and data cleaning, in combination with morphemes and gloss (above). If you want to use it, you can choose to use any sort of LaTeX Tree package (we use QTree by default) Sample entry: \Tree [.S NP VP ]
datumFields.helpLinguists: This optional field is used by the machine to make LaTeX trees and help with search and data cleaning, in combination with morphemes and gloss (above). If you want to use it, you can choose to use any sort of LaTeX Tree package (we use QTree by default) Sample entry: \Tree [.S NP VP ]

conversationFields.help: Use this field to keep track of who your speaker is. You can use names, initials, or whatever your consultants prefer.
conversationFields.helpLinguists: Use this field to keep track of who your speaker is. You can use names, initials, or whatever your consultants prefer.

conversationFields.help: Use this field to indicate if this is a voice or gesture tier, or a tier for another modality.
conversationFields.helpLinguists: Use this field to indicate if this is a voice or gesture tier, or a tier for another modality.

sessionFields.help: The goals of the elicitation session. Why did you get together today, was it the second day of field methods class, or you wanted to collect some stories from you grandmother, or was it to check on some data you found in the literature...
sessionFields.helpLinguists: The goals of the elicitation session. Why did you get together today, was it the second day of field methods class, or you wanted to collect some stories from you grandmother, or was it to check on some data you found in the literature...

sessionFields.help: This is a comma seperated field of all the consultants/publications/sources who were were the source/present for this elicitation session.
sessionFields.helpLinguists: This is a comma seperated field of all the consultants/publications/sources who  were were the source/present for this elicitation session.
sessionFields.helpDevelopers: This is a comma seperated field of all the consultants (usernames, or anonymouse codes, or publication uri's) who were present for this elicitation session. This field also contains a (hidden) array of consultant/source masks if they are actual users of the system.

sessionFields.help: Dialect of this example (city, village, region etc)
sessionFields.helpLinguists: This dialect may precise as the team chooses (province, region, city, village or any other measure of dialect)

sessionFields.help: Social register of this example (friends, children speaking with children, formal, religious, ceremonial etc)
sessionFields.helpLinguists: This is an optional field which indicates the social register of the example (friends, children speaking with children, formal, religious, ceremonial etc)

sessionFields.help: This is the langauge name (or language family), it is optionally tied to an Ethnologue language code (ISO 639-3).
sessionFields.helpLinguists: This is the langauge (or language family), there is optional extra information fields if your team wants to tie it to an Ethnologe three letter language code (ISO 639-3).

sessionFields.help: This is the GPS location of the elicitation session (if available)
sessionFields.helpLinguists: This is the GPS location of the elicitation session (if available)

sessionFields.help: The date when the elicitation session took place, or when the datum was spoken/published.
sessionFields.helpLinguists: The date when the elicitation session took place, or when the datum was spoken/published.

sessionFields.help: This is a comma seperated field of all the people who were present for this elicitation session, or authors/reviewers of the publication.
sessionFields.helpLinguists: This is a comma seperated field of all the people who were present for this elicitation session, or authors/reviewers of the publication.
sessionFields.helpDevelopers: This is a comma seperated field of all the people who were present for this elicitation session. This field also contains a (hidden) array of user masks with more details about the people present, if they are not anonymous or are actual users of the system.

sessionFields.help: The date when the elicitation session data was actually entered in the computer (could be different from the dateElicited, especailly if you usually elicit data with an audio recorder and/or a note book).
sessionFields.helpLinguists: The date when the elicitation session data was actually entered in the computer (could be different from the dateElicited, especailly if you usually elicit data with an audio recorder and/or a note book).

sessionFields.help: The optional device details of the equipment used to record the elicitation session. This can be useful for measuring phonetic quality of the recording etc. eg: Nexus 7 Android 4.1
sessionFields.helpLinguists: The optional device details of the equipment used to record the elicitation session. This can be useful for measuring phonetic quality of the recording etc. eg: Nexus 7 Android 4.1
sessionFields.helpDevelopers: Your app can save optional anonymous device details of the equipment/software which used to record the elicitation session. This can be useful for measuring phonetic quality of the recording etc. eg: Nexus 7 Android 4.1

speakerFields.help: A field to anonymously identify language speakers/participants.
speakerFields.helpLinguists: A field to anonymously identify language consultants/informants/experiment participants (by default it can be a timestamp, or a combination of experimenter initials, speaker/participant initials etc).

speakerFields.help: The first name of the speaker/participant (optional, encrypted if speaker is anonymous)
speakerFields.helpLinguists: The first name of the speaker/participant (optional, should be encrypted if speaker should remain anonymous)

speakerFields.help: The last name of the speaker/participant (encrypted)
speakerFields.helpLinguists: The last name of the speaker/participant (optional, encrypted if speaker should remain anonymous)

speakerFields.help: Optional username of the speaker/participant, if the speaker/participant is registered in the system (encrypted).
speakerFields.helpLinguists: Optional username of the speaker/participant, if the speaker/participant is registered in the system (encrypted).

speakerFields.help: Optional date of birth of the speaker/participant, if used by the experimental analysis (ie speaker/participants of 20 months performed differently from speaker/participants of 22 months).
speakerFields.helpLinguists: Optional date of birth of the speaker/participant, if used by the experimental analysis (ie speaker/participants of 20 months performed differently from speaker/participants of 22 months).

speakerFields.help: Optional gender or biological sex of the speaker/participant, if used by the speaker/participants result reports or experimental analysis.
speakerFields.helpLinguists: Optional gender or biological sex of the speaker/participant, if used by the speaker/participants result reports or experimental analysis.

speakerFields.help: This is the langauge name (or language family), it is optionally tied to an Ethnologue language code (ISO 639-3).
speakerFields.helpLinguists: This is the langauge (or language family), there is optional extra information fields if your team wants to tie it to an Ethnologe three letter language code (ISO 639-3).

speakerFields.help: Confidentiality setting of this speaker. By default the speaker is anonymous which means data can be associated to one speaker, but the speaker cannot be identified) hidden means data will be associated to the entire speaker population of the corpus, team means that team members can see the consultant's identity, but the outsiders of the team can only see an anonymous user, public means the speaker has signed a consent form and has asked that his/her data to be associated his/her user account or identity.
speakerFields.helpLinguists: Confidentiality setting of this speaker. By default the speaker is anonymous which means data can be associated to the speaker, but the speaker cannot be identified) hidden means data will be associated to the entire speaker population of the corpus, team means that team members can see the consultant's identity, but the outsiders of the team can only see an anonymous user, public means the speaker has signed a consent form and has asked that his/her data to be associated his/her user account or identity.
